questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with recurrent bleeding. Diagnostic imaging reveals that the bleeding is from the posterior nasal cavity. Which artery, derived from the maxillary artery, is most likely responsible for this condition?

A 35-year-old patient presents with frequent episodes of anterior epistaxis, which are mild and self-limiting. Examination reveals the bleeding site to be in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Which vascular network is most likely involved in this case?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Branch of

Sphenopalatine artery

Maxillary artery

Anterior ethmoidal artery

Ophthalmic artery (from internal carotid artery)

Greater palatine artery

Maxillary artery

Superior labial artery

Facial artery (from external carotid artery)

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of mild anterior epistaxis, mainly from the nasal septum. Upon examination, the source of the bleeding is traced to a venous structure near the anterior septum. Which of the following veins is most likely responsible for the bleeding?

A 65-year-old male with hypertension presents with profuse nasal bleeding from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, unresponsive to pinching and anterior packing. Nasal endoscopy shows bleeding behind the middle turbinate. What is the likely source of bleeding and appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Anterior Epistaxis

Posterior Epistaxis

Definition

Bleeding from the front of the nose

Bleeding that flows backwards into the throat

Source of bleeding

Kiesselbach's plexus
(Anterior ethmoidal artery, Septal branch of Superior labial artery, Septal branch of Sphenopalatine artery, Greater palatine artery)
  • Sphenopalatine artery (Most common)
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

Site

Little's area (anteroinferior nasal septum)

Posterior or superior parts of the nasal cavity (e.g.Woodruff's plexus)

Age Group

Mostly in children and young adults

More common in adults over 40 years old

Usual Cause

Trauma (e.g., nose picking, injury)

Spontaneous, often associated with hypertension and arteriosclerosis

Management

Local pressure and conservative measures

Postnasal pack, more aggressive treatment often required

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of mild epistaxis. On examination, the bleeding site is found in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. What could be the most common cause of epistaxis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Causes and Common Sites of Epistaxis in Different Age Groups

Age Group

Most Common Cause

Most Common Site

Children/Young Adults

Nasal trauma (nose-picking)

Kiesselbach's plexus (anterior nasal septum)

Older Adults

Hypertension

Woodruff’s plexus (posterior nasal cavity)

All Ages

Infections or dryness

Kiesselbach's plexus (anterior nasal septum)

Hereditary Conditions

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia

Multiple sites in the nasal cavity

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with anterior epistaxis after sustaining a nose injury. Despite initial first aid measures, bleeding continues, and a bleeding point is identified. What is the most appropriate next step if the bleeding persists?
questions.explanation:
First Line:

(Direct therapy)
  • First Aid:
    • Hippocrates method: Pinch the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes to control bleeding, especially from Little’s area.
    • Trotter’s Method: Have the patient sit forward over a basin to spit blood and breathe through the mouth. Apply cold compresses to induce vasoconstriction.
 
  • Cauterization:
    • Indication: Effective for anterior epistaxis when the bleeding point is identified.
    • Apply topical anaesthesia and cauterize with silver nitrate or electrocautery.

Second Line: (Indirect therapy)
  • Anterior Nasal Packing: Clear the nasal cavity of blood clots, localise the bleeding site, and pack with ribbon gauze soaked in liquid paraffin. The packing may need to stay for 24-72 hours with systemic antibiotics to prevent infection.
 
  • Posterior Nasal Packing:
    • Use a cone-shaped gauze pack and a rubber catheter or nasal balloon. The pack is guided into the nasopharynx, with an anterior nasal pack to stabilize.
    • Patients need to be hospitalised & balloons with separate bulbs for the postnasal space and nasal cavity are used.

Third Line:

(Surgical Interventions)

  
  • Ligation of Vessels:
    • Maxillary Artery: Ligation via Caldwell-Luc operation for uncontrollable posterior epistaxis.
    • Ethmoidal Arteries: for bleeding from above the middle turbinate.
    • External Carotid: Ligate above the superior thyroid artery for persistent bleeding from the external carotid system.
  • Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL): Locate and ligate the Sphenopalatine artery (Artery of Epistaxis) to control refractory posterior bleeding. (Option D)

Fourth Line (Embolization)

(Option C)

Performed by an interventional radiologist through femoral artery catheterisation using absorbable gel foam or coils. It may require bilateral embolisation for unilateral bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is most appropriate when ligating the anterior ethmoidal artery to control anterior epistaxis?

A 45-year-old patient with Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia presents with recurrent epistaxis despite conservative measures. Which of the following treatments is considered the last resort for severe, persistent bleeding that has not responded?
Match the following types of fractures with respective findings. Type of Fracture Finding 1. Jarjavay Fracture a) 2. Class III Nasal Fracture b) 3. Chevallet Fracture c)
questions.explanation:
Class I (Chevallet Fracture)

Class II (Jarjavay Fracture)

Class III (Naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture)

Cause

Blows from below

Impacts directed from the front

High-velocity trauma

Fracture Line

Vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

Horizontal fracture starting just above the anterior nasal spine, running backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage and vomer.

Involves external buttresses of the nose and ethmoid labyrinth.

Pig-like appearance with foreshortened, saddled nose.

Clinical Relations
  • Assess for nasal obstruction and deformity.
  • Significant deformity might only develop later, especially in children.
  • Check for deviation greater than half the width of the nose, which may indicate a septal fracture.
  • Requires reduction of both nasal and septal fractures.
  • Look for signs of more severe injuries, such as CSF leaks, multiple dural tears, and potential cerebral herniation.
  • Evaluate for orbital and skull base involvement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a nasal fracture from a frontal blow during a sports accident. The nasal bridge is deviated with swelling and bruising. The patient reports nasal obstruction, but no other facial fractures are noted. What is the most appropriate management approach?
questions.correct_answer: C. Closed reduction after oedema subsides
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis
  • Physical Examination is the best method for diagnosing nasal fractures. Look for signs such as swelling, periorbital ecchymosis, tenderness, nasal deformity, crepitus, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction.
  • X-rays: These may not always reveal fractures. Necessary views include Waters’ view, lateral views, and occlusal view.

Treatment
  • Simple Fractures: Generally, no treatment is required if there's no displacement. Monitor for natural healing.
  • Closed Reduction:
    • Timing: Ideally performed before significant edema develops or after it subsides (Option C) (usually 5-7 days).
    • Technique:
      • Use a straight blunt elevator guided by digital manipulation from outside for depressed fractures.
      • Reduce laterally displaced nasal bridge with firm digital pressure in the opposite direction.
      • Disimpaction of impacted fragments requires Walsham or Asch’s forceps.
      • Septal fractures and hematomas should be managed with Asch’s forceps.
    • Packing: Unstable fractures require intranasal packing and external splintage.
  • Open Reduction (Option B): Rarely required early & Considered if closed methods fail, for certain septal injuries & if a patient presents late.
  • Correction of Deformities: May need rhinoplasty or septorhinoplasty for healed deformities from trauma.

questions.text: During a closed reduction procedure for a nasal septum, the surgeon selected a forceps, as depicted in the image, and asked the intern to identify it. What is the name of these forceps?

A 32-year-old female involved in a car accident presents to the emergency department with a hanging palate and hanging teeth after her face collided with the dashboard. All of the following are true regarding this type of fracture, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Referred to as a transverse maxillary fracture

options.label: D
options.text: Fracture line traverses the nasal and maxillary sinus floors

questions.correct_answer: C. High risk of CSF rhinorrhea

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe facial pain, swelling, and trouble closing his mouth after a high-impact fall. Examination shows a hanging maxilla. What type of fracture does this indicate?
questions.correct_answer: B. Le Fort type II fracture
questions.explanation:
Le Fort I

(Option A)

Le Fort II

(Option B)

Le Fort III

(Option C)

Also known as

Guerin’s fracture or Transverse fracture

Pyramidal fracture

Craniofacial disjunction

Fracture line

Runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates.

Passes through the nasal root, lacrimal bone, orbital floor, upper maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates

 

Note: can cause infraorbital nerve injury.

Traverses the root of the nose, ethmoid-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and the upper pterygoid plates.

Characteristic feature

Hanging palate and hanging teeth

Hanging maxilla

Complete detachment of the facial bones from the cranial bones

CSF Rhinorrhea

Absent

May be present

High risk of CSF Rhinorrhea

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with jaw pain, swelling, difficulty opening his mouth, and trouble chewing after being struck in the face during a fight. What is the most common site for mandibular fractures?

A 22-year-old woman reports experiencing pain, swelling, blurred vision, and double vision following a facial injury from a basketball. Based on the clinical presentation and radiograph findings, which extraocular muscle is most likely restricted, leading to impaired eye movement?
questions.explanation:
Cause

A large blunt object striking the eye globe.

Location

The floor of the orbit.

Clinical features

  • Ecchymosis of the lid, conjunctiva and sclera.
  • Enophthalmos with inferior displacement of the eyeball.
  • Diplopia (displacement of the eyeball or entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles).
  • Hypoaesthesia or anaesthesia of the cheek and upper lip (infraorbital nerve involvement).
  • Presence of periorbital emphysema and oedema.
  • Restricted eye movement (entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle)

Forced duction test
  • To determine if the inferior rectus muscle is impinged at the fracture site.
  • A small forceps is used to release the muscle from the fracture site. Improvement in eye movement suggests muscle impingement.

Diagnosis

X-ray and CT scan shows the characteristic “teardrop” sign due to herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus.

Management

  • Reduction (Indicated if associated with zygomatic/maxillary fractures or significant functional impairment)
  • Surgery is required for persistent diplopia, enophthalmos, or muscle entrapment. It typically involves reconstructing the orbital floor to correct anatomical displacement and relieve symptoms.
